> > How is  [example truncated] better than just declaring the test 
> > to be able to throw SomeException?
> 
> If nothing else, the Assert.fail(e) indicates that it is a test
> failure, rather than a test error.  You can use this as an early clue
> that whatever you broke is a case that is actually under test.

I would agree. I spend a lot of time in my unit tests writing the structure:

public void testWhatever() {
   setup_stuff_here();
   more_setup_stuff_here();
   try {
      method_under_test();
   } catch(Exception e) {
      fail(e.getMessage());
   }
}

because an error indicates an exception thrown by functionality NOT under
test. An exception thrown by functionality that IS under test is properly
reported as a failure (the implicit assertion is that there will be no
exception thrown).

It would be more expressive to simply be able to call fail(e), and would
make more semantic information available to test run environments that could
make use of it.

- John
